title: Michelia
text:
Michelia is a historical <a href="genus">genus</a> of <a href="flowering%20plant">flowering plant</a>s belonging to the <a href="Magnolia">Magnolia</a> family (<a href="Magnoliaceae">Magnoliaceae</a>). The genus included about 50 <a href="species">species</a> of <a href="evergreen">evergreen</a> <a href="tree">tree</a>s and <a href="shrub">shrub</a>s, native to tropical and subtropical <a href="south%20Asia">south</a> and <a href="southeast%20Asia">southeast Asia</a> (<a href="Indomalaya">Indomalaya</a>), including southern <a href="China">China</a>. Today it is regarded as a <a href="synonym%20%28taxonomy%29">synonym</a> of "<a href="Magnolia">Magnolia</a>".
Description.
The Magnoliaceae are an ancient family; fossil plants identifiably belonging to the Magnoliaceae date back 95 million years. A primitive aspect of the Magnolia family is that their large, cup-shaped <a href="flower">flower</a>s lack distinct <a href="petal">petal</a>s or <a href="sepal">sepal</a>s. The large non-specialized flower parts, resembling petals, are called <a href="tepal">tepal</a>s.
The leaves, flowers, and form of "Michelia" resemble "Magnolia", but the blossoms of "Michelia" generally form clusters among the leaves, rather than singly at the branch ends as "Magnolia" does.
Uses.
Several of the larger species are locally important sources of <a href="timber">timber</a>. Some species, including the champak "(<a href="Michelia%20champaca">Michelia champaca</a>)" and "<a href="Michelia%20doltsopa">Michelia doltsopa</a>" are grown for their flowers, both on the tree and as cut flowers. Champak flowers are also used to produce an <a href="essential%20oil">essential oil</a> for perfume. A few species have been introduced to gardens or as street trees outside of the Indomalaya region, including "<a href="Michelia%20figo">Michelia figo</a>", "M. doltsopa", and "M. champaca." The genus is named after the <a href="Florence">Florentine</a> <a href="botany">botanist</a> <a href="Pietro%20Antonio%20Micheli">Pietro Antonio Micheli</a> (1679–1737). They grow to the height of 10–45 metres
Recent changes in classification.
Morphological data and molecular data recently showed that the genus "Michelia" is very closely related to subgenus "Yulania" of genus "Magnolia". Many botanists now treat the genus "Michelia" accordingly. New combinations of names have been provided for. For further information see under genus "<a href="Magnolia">Magnolia</a>".
